values.alignmentText: Exceptional environmental standards, clean water, and extensive protected areas.
Low sea-level risk; alpine heat/drought and glacier melt impacts.
Temperate overall: mild summers, cool winters; low humidity in lowlands.
Consistently good air quality outside occasional urban corridors.
Generally low risk; localized floods/avalanches/landslides in alpine areas.
Lowlands ~8-18 C (46-64 F); frequent rain; lengthening daylight.
Lowlands ~20-28 C (68-82 F); low humidity; lakes offer relief.
Cooling to ~8-16 C (46-61 F); fog in some valleys; stable weather.
Lowlands ~-1-6 C (30-43 F); colder in alpine regions; periodic snow/ice.
No sea beaches; lakes and river baths are delightful in summer.
Lake swimming mainly late June-Aug; otherwise chilly.
World-class Alps and lakes; unparalleled hiking and scenic rail.
No federal minimum; several cantons set high floors (CHF/hr).
Very high compensation, offset by high living costs.
Solid demand in finance, pharma, and enterprise (Zurich/Basel).
Moderate market; roles clustered in major cities.
Feasible but non-EU quotas and cantonal approvals add friction.
Stable, diversified economy with low unemployment and strong CHF.
Hybrid/remote acceptable in tech; many firms still prefer on-site.
Clear boundaries; generous leave culture vs. US norms.
~40-42 typical; legal caps by sector; overtime regulated.
Statutory leave guarantees 20 paid days (25 for younger staff) plus canton holidays, so Sarah can reliably plan family breaks.
Most tech employers grant 25–30 days plus holidays, letting Trey and Sarah schedule longer US visits or alpine getaways without pushback.
Calm and orderly; slower rhythm outside Zurich/Geneva.
Schools often have midday breaks; after-school care needed; offices ~08:30-17:30.
Outdoors, day trips, and sports; Sunday retail closures.
Exceptionally safe with abundant parks and family amenities.
Polyamorous families stay discreet outside major cities; Zurich/Geneva scenes exist but legal frameworks stay strictly monogamous.
Structured and independence-oriented; moderate extracurricular load.
Excellent playgrounds, clean public spaces, safe streets.
Strong public schools; language tracks; quality international schools are costly.
Kitas reliable but expensive; availability varies by city/canton.
Municipal subsidies reduce Kita bills for some incomes, yet most parents still shoulder significant costs despite political promises.
Non-EU residents can access subsidies only after local tax registration, and canton quotas keep many visa families paying near full price.
Free, high-quality public system; local catchments; secular options.
Resident children enroll in public schools; integration support available.
Available (incl. international/Montessori); admissions selective; fees high.
Child allowances and 14-week maternity leave help, yet benefits are lean compared with Nordic standards and paperwork varies by canton.
B-permit families qualify once they pay into social insurance, but shorter leave and canton discretion limit predictable support.
Top universities with relatively low tuition; language prerequisites.
Non-EU students often pay modest tuition; scholarships limited.
Egalitarian trend with some traditional patterns persisting by region.
Legal recognition improving; social acceptance higher in cities.
Strong workplace equality laws and protections.
Practical, understated style; safety and independence emphasized.
Reserved, pragmatic; caregiving roles increasingly normalized.
Alps, precision culture, and serene, reliable daily life.
English common in business; daily life benefits from German/French/Italian.
Socially liberal overall; direct democracy yields mixed outcomes.
Limited; politics center on pragmatic market-social balance.
Secular society with plural religious presence.
Comprehensive sex-ed; public norms modest; cities more open.
Same-sex marriage/legal protections; acceptance strong in urban areas.
Reserved at first; deep relationships form through schools/clubs.
Neutral, precise, community-minded with high civic pride.
Cooperative with EU neighbors; tightly connected cross-border.

values.key: View of Them by Neighboring Countries
values.alignmentText: Seen as wealthy, orderly, and occasionally insular.
Good in Zurich/Geneva/Lausanne; quieter elsewhere; early closures.
Smart-casual, technical outerwear; understated quality.
Practical chic; layered for weather; modest silhouettes.
Hiking, skiing, cycling, lake swimming; youth sports popular.
Active clubs and shops; smaller scene than Germany.
Vibrant festivals (e.g., Montreux Jazz); lively city venues.
Strong meetup culture in big cities; English-speaking groups.
Trailheads by train; car-free peaks; weekend trips are easy.
Federal direct democracy; frequent referenda; strong local control.
Limited church influence; secular policy norms.
Solid protections and social insurance; less interventionist than Nordics.
Liberal market economy with robust but lean safety nets.
Very low given institutions and civic participation.
High-trust, high-productivity capitalism with strong SMEs.
Exceptional economic and political stability.
Independent media landscape; low state narrative pressure.
Public broadcasters emphasize neutrality/civic duty.
Comprehensive insurance and benefits, though less expansive than Nordics.
High trust supported by transparency and local voice.
Among the lowest globally.
Occasional corporate/compliance issues; petty corruption rare.
Very high rents and tight supply in major cities; low ownership.
Extremely safe; violent crime rare; excellent emergency services.
Mandatory private insurance with excellent quality; premiums high.
Must obtain local insurance; access comparable; short waits.
Quality care exists but waits and high fees mean we stitch together Kitas, neighbor help, and remote days to cover gaps.
Stable, safe, outdoors-oriented life; benefits adequate but lean.
High PISA outcomes; bilingual exposure possible; early tracking.
World-class rail/bus network; punctual and comprehensive.
Competitive market economy with social insurance pillars.
Withholding (Quellensteuer) for some B permits; filings vary by canton.
Varies widely by canton/commune; mid-range overall for cities.
Modern payments (TWINT); US persons face FATCA-related onboarding hurdles.
Very high costs, especially housing, childcare, and dining.
Three-pillar system (AHV/AVS + occupational + private) ensures coverage.
Second-pillar portability/refunds possible on departure; treaty nuances.
Non-EU hiring under quotas; L/B permits; self-employment/startup routes narrow.
Skilled Americans welcomed, but processes are selective and quota-bound.
L (short-stay) and B (residence) renewable; C (permanent) after long residence.
Typically ~10 years residency with language/integration; communal/cantonal steps.
Family reunification available; spouse work rights depend on permit type.
Processing is orderly but not fast; fees and insurance costs add up.
Register with commune, maintain insurance, observe permit quotas/taxes.
Yes, dual nationality permitted for naturalized citizens.
US banking (FATCA), high deposits for rentals, and language needs.
Small but present scene; roles limited compared to major hubs.
GIANTS Software (Zurich) and several indies/university labs.
SGDA network; city-level meetups and student groups.
Support via Pro Helvetia SwissGames and Innosuisse programs.
Gigabit fiber common; Azure regions in-country; trains/grid are first-rate.

Frequent abrupt changes make certain months feel unstable with several days of hazardous conditions that push us indoors. Seasonal Weather at 6/10 and Natural Disasters at 7/10 steer the family toward a mixed outlook for seasonal extremes & variability.

Deep winter gloom lasts several weeks, so we plan strict routines, supplements, and possible getaways to maintain morale. Seasonal Weather at 6/10 and Environment at 9/10 steer the family toward a strong outlook for seasonal sunlight hours.

Roughly half the year is wonderful, half demands planning around heat, cold, or rain to enjoy time outside. Seasonal Weather at 6/10 and Environment at 9/10 steer the family toward a strong outlook for pleasant weather windows.

High living costs erode quality of life; reliable childcare or healthcare coverage often falls through the cracks. Minimum Wage at 5/10, Housing Situation at 4/10, and Childcare Support (Citizens) at 5/10 steer the family toward a mixed outlook for quality of life – lower-income tier.

Comfortable living is possible but major purchases or travel demand careful planning and occasional sacrifices. Typical Software Salaries at 9/10, Housing Situation at 4/10, and Work-Life Balance at 8/10 steer the family toward a strong outlook for quality of life – middle-income tier.

Affluent households encounter noticeable friction—specialists, tutors, or clubs are scarce or highly gated. Housing Situation at 4/10, Private Education at 6/10, and Family Life at 8/10 steer the family toward a mixed outlook for quality of life – higher-income tier.

values.key: Spacious Housing Benchmark (2k sq ft Rent)
values.alignmentText: Only a handful of listings surface each year; expect bidding wars and significant trade-offs. Housing Situation at 4/10 and Cost of Living (Optional) at 3/10 steer the family toward a challenging outlook for spacious housing benchmark (2k sq ft rent).

Opportunities are sporadic; we rely on informal networks or satellite towns to join community living models. Community Vibes at 5/10, Meetups & Communities at 7/10, and Family Life at 8/10 steer the family toward a mixed outlook for community living opportunities.

Surface politeness exists yet deeper support systems take sustained effort to unlock. Community Vibes at 5/10, Meetups & Communities at 7/10, and Common Hobbies at 9/10 steer the family toward a mixed outlook for friendliness & neighborliness index.

Immigrants are tolerated but face regular microaggressions or bureaucratic hurdles. Welcoming of US Migrants at 5/10, Progressivism at 7/10, and Language & English Ubiquity at 6/10 steer the family toward a mixed outlook for immigrant sentiment – general.

Noticeable grumbles about expats driving up costs or staying in enclaves; we mitigate by community engagement. Welcoming of US Migrants at 5/10, Language & English Ubiquity at 6/10, and View of Them by Neighboring Countries at 6/10 steer the family toward a mixed outlook for immigrant sentiment – white migrants.

Interactions can be efficient yet emotionally flat; kindness takes effort to elicit. Community Vibes at 5/10, Nightlife Culture at 6/10, and Common Hobbies at 9/10 steer the family toward a mixed outlook for surface interaction norms.

Many acquaintances stay casual, but dedicated outreach unlocks close friendships over time. Community Vibes at 5/10, Meetups & Communities at 7/10, and What Is Intriguing at 9/10 steer the family toward a strong outlook for depth-seeking social norms.

Personal space is often compressed, so we must advocate gently for comfort. Community Vibes at 5/10, Sex (Attitudes) at 6/10, and View of self at 8/10 steer the family toward a mixed outlook for personal boundary & bubble norms.

Openness is usually welcomed though some contexts expect diplomacy and softening of hard truths. Progressivism at 7/10, What Is Intriguing at 9/10, and Trust in Government at 8/10 steer the family toward a strong outlook for moral, honesty & openness expectations.

Noticeable emphasis on grooming means we budget extra time and money to fit in. Fashion Trends (Male) at 6/10 and Fashion Trends (Female) at 6/10 steer the family toward a mixed outlook for grooming & beauty investment.

Diet talk and body critiques surface regularly in social circles. Fashion Trends (Male) at 6/10, Fashion Trends (Female) at 6/10, and Sex (Attitudes) at 6/10 steer the family toward a mixed outlook for body image & fitness pressure.

Fashionable appearance is expected in many settings, adding planning time and costs. Fashion Trends (Male) at 6/10 and Fashion Trends (Female) at 6/10 steer the family toward a mixed outlook for fashion & style expectations.

Boundaries are understood yet alcohol-fueled scenes need watchfulness. Sex (Attitudes) at 6/10, LGBTQ+ Attitudes at 8/10, and Nightlife Culture at 6/10 steer the family toward a strong outlook for flirting boundaries & consent culture.

Traditional norms dominate mainstream spaces, limiting how our family models relationships. Gender Roles at 6/10, Gender Fluidity at 6/10, and Sex (Attitudes) at 6/10 steer the family toward a mixed outlook for gendered flirting expectations.

Non-monogamy is tolerated in niche scenes but draws judgment elsewhere. Polyamory at 4/10, Sex (Attitudes) at 6/10, and Community Vibes at 5/10 steer the family toward a mixed outlook for monogamy vs. non-monogamy acceptance.

Moralizing comments surface regularly, pushing us to stay private about experiences. Sex (Attitudes) at 6/10, Nightlife & Music at 6/10, and Community Vibes at 5/10 steer the family toward a mixed outlook for promiscuity attitudes.

Multi-partner families keep a low profile to avoid gossip or discrimination. Polyamory at 4/10, Community Vibes at 5/10, and LGBTQ+ Attitudes at 8/10 steer the family toward a mixed outlook for group & multi-partner relationship attitudes.

Tight quarters and spontaneous touch are common; advocating for space is a regular task. Community Vibes at 5/10, Sex (Attitudes) at 6/10, and Nightlife Culture at 6/10 steer the family toward a mixed outlook for personal space & touch norms.

Ownership exists but licensing, storage, and training rules are rigorous and widely respected. Safety & Crime at 10/10, State Ideology at 7/10, and Political System at 10/10 steer the family toward an excellent outlook for firearm laws & ownership culture.

Light penalties and robust health services keep substance issues managed compassionately. Progressivism at 7/10, Political System at 10/10, and Safety & Crime at 10/10 steer the family toward an excellent outlook for controlled substance policies.

Police practices are proportionate with strong oversight; families rarely witness aggressive sweeps. Safety & Crime at 10/10, Progressivism at 7/10, and Authoritarian Backsliding Risk at 9/10 steer the family toward an excellent outlook for drug enforcement climate.

Mass violence is exceptionally rare and institutions have robust prevention plans and drills. Safety & Crime at 10/10 and Stability at 10/10 steer the family toward an excellent outlook for mass violence incidence.

Prisons meet international standards with active oversight and restorative programs. Authoritarian Backsliding Risk at 9/10, Safety & Crime at 10/10, and Perceived Corruption at 9/10 steer the family toward an excellent outlook for carceral conditions & prison labor.

Walkable pockets exist and connect via decent transit; we plan routes to avoid busy arterials. Public Transportation at 10/10, Housing Situation at 4/10, and Nature Access at 10/10 steer the family toward a strong outlook for walkability & pedestrian safety.

We can find wellness support but must seek out likeminded circles to stay motivated. Healthcare (Citizens) at 8/10, Work-Life Balance at 8/10, and Community Vibes at 5/10 steer the family toward a strong outlook for community health consciousness.

Maintaining clean eating requires vigilance and possibly specialty stores. Cost of Living (Optional) at 3/10, Community Health Consciousness at 7/10, and Fresh & International Cuisine Access at 7/10 steer the family toward a mixed outlook for processed food saturation.

We can meet most cravings but specialty ingredients or restaurants appear sporadically. Nightlife & Music at 6/10, Common Hobbies at 9/10, and Meetups & Communities at 7/10 steer the family toward a strong outlook for fresh & international cuisine access.

Higher-than-average depression rates prompt us to plan carefully for therapy access. Seasonal Weather at 6/10, Work-Life Balance at 8/10, and Community Vibes at 5/10 steer the family toward a mixed outlook for depression prevalence.

Higher obesity prevalence indicates limited access to healthy routines in some areas. Community Health Consciousness at 7/10, Work-Life Balance at 8/10, and Cost of Living (Optional) at 3/10 steer the family toward a mixed outlook for obesity rate.

Rates align with global norms; screening and early detection programs are reliable. Environment at 9/10, Healthcare (Citizens) at 8/10, and Community Health Consciousness at 7/10 steer the family toward a strong outlook for cancer incidence.

Resilience is good with occasional layoffs offset by quick reemployment. Economic Health at 9/10, Remote-Friendly Culture at 6/10, and Typical Software Salaries at 9/10 steer the family toward a strong outlook for broader job market resilience.
